abstract.text: Constants that specify the orientation of the app’s user interface.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Starting in iOS 8, you should employ the
APIs, and size class properties as used in those APIs, instead of using
constants or otherwise writing your app in terms of interface orientation.
In earlier versions of iOS, you used these constants in the
. The reason for this is that rotating the device requires rotating the content in the opposite direction.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An exception that’s thrown if a view controller or the app returns an invalid set of supported interface orientations.
Sets the app’s status bar to the specified orientation, optionally animating the transition.
The current orientation of the app’s status bar.
Asks the delegate for the interface orientations to use for the view controllers in the specified window.
The device is in landscape mode, with the device held upright and the front-facing camera on the left side.
The device is in landscape mode, with the device held upright and the front-facing camera on the right side.
Constants that specify the orientation of the app’s user interface.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the user interface is currently presented in a landscape orientation.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the user interface is currently presented in a portrait orientation.
The device is in landscape mode, with the device upright and the Home button on the left.
The device is in landscape mode, with the device upright and the Home button on the right.
The device is in portrait mode, with the device upright and the Home button on the bottom.
The device is in portrait mode but is upside down, with the device upright and the Home button at the top.
The orientation of the device is unknown.
Constants that specify a view controller’s supported interface orientations.
A collection of data that represents the environment for an individual element in your app’s user interface.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
Describes an integer.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type that can be converted to and from an associated raw value.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
